data.author: PaulJ8520
data.content: On the voting proxy thing it says;;; "Use of Proceeds Approximately £1.4 million of the net proceeds of the Subscription will be used to expedite the Company’s exploration programme at the Homase Mine in Ghana, with the objective of expanding and enhancing the current JORC Resource, together with supporting business administration and working capital requirements. The Company plans to use the remaining funds to invest in gold projects outside Ghana, aiming to diversify its asset base and enhance Shareholder value. It is currently in advanced discussions regarding a potential investment in a company with gold assets in Sierra Leone. No binding agreements have been made yet, and the Company will provide further updates if any such agreements are finalised." So not an acquisition. I'd rather have the remaining ploughed into Homase, but I couldn't vote on that, such a shame. Does it mean they think they have enough funds coming in from Homase to continue expansion? I wonder!

data.author: booboouberbear
data.content: 1nvest, It's abundantly clear last year H2 has seen a meltdown in stacking. Why was this? Skill? CAPEX issues? Rain? Regulatory Inspections? All 4? But if / when they sort it out, there is capacity here with existing infrastructure on the ground to stack 672k tonnes and produce circa 14k troy ounces. I make that somewhere in the region of 5 to 10p a share if you can get AISCs at $2.5k an ounce. It's always been an insane risk v reward proposition here, and its getting less and less risky.

data.author: banjomick
data.content: A reminder from the last RNS and yes I take fully on-board the lack of 'targets' being met over the years but GRL in their current form are a relatively new company going from exploration to producer: "We are pleased to have conditionally raised £2.0 million, which strengthens the Company's balance sheet and provides funding to accelerate exploration at the Homase Mine while also enabling us to consider additional opportunities beyond our core asset. data.author: banjomick
data.content: Hi ID, got rained off from gardening work, horrible out there! I know you asked boo but I to would expect an improvement in gold production from the next update for a few reasons: 1. It's the dry season now, therefore no delays from rainfall 2.  "A new screening and conveying system was completed and commissioned in December 2025, enabling stacking rates of up to 56,000 tonnes of agglomerated ore per month, providing increased operational flexibility." That's obviously depending on whether it's on-line and working after commissioning! 3. "The mining schedule has been restructured to maximise production during drier operational periods" 4. With the new board now settled in, by the sounds of it overseeing day to day activities, along with lessons learnt and the experience gained over the last two years or so, should make the whole process more efficient yielding greater gold production..........in theory! :-)

data.author: Iceman_1
data.content: What a great start to the week!!! 🔥 This RNS is exactly the type of news that typically re-rates a small AIM mining stock:- Contractor signed = Execution underway No longer plans, this is action. Kuboc isn’t just engaged — it’s mobilising. Mining timeline now defined A February start gives the market a clear near-term event to price in. Revenue visibility beginning With first sales expected this quarter, NTVO is on the verge of moving toward cash flow — the key value driver. Scale-up potential The production targets grow over time, which means higher throughput and potentially more gold sold as the mine ramps. We’re now on a clear upward trajectory. What you’re seeing is a re-rate as the company transitions from explorer → producer.

data.author: wasarunner
data.content: Quick maths and so it may be wrong and/or the website info out of date. AIMS: 144m new shares + 249m old shares = 393m shares for their new 29.9999999999999% holding mystery investor: 200m new shares for their 17% ish holding mystery investor converts another 200m new shares, probably 30% shareholding of the enlarged shareholding at that point AIMS convert a few $ accrued interest into shares Presto: the two units hold 60%. You'll know after EGM anyway because at 17% they'll have to declare. Paracle have just about too few shares now that 17%+existing shares wouldn't put them over 30% so it's possible. But my bet is it's (really) AIMS, and when the warrant exercise they own 60% and the show. It's tempting as a trade - but I don't trust EP enough :) good luck those that do!

data.author: Fr.Jack.Hackett
data.content: Mr 05, ". . could you please tell me why you are invested in Goldstone resources. . ", sorry - I do not join in such irrelevant discussion. I am interested in GRL based on their historic RNS statements going back to 2019/2020. Please read - especially the ones released throughout 2022 - they make as good reading as the script to faulty towers. Prospects going forward! - wonderful if you believe even half the wording in the RNS !! The use of the word "believe" in that statement is the main issue. If gold grades are there (and I have doubts) - then I am sure the Homase mine can be profitable (if no debt attached - such as the gold loan). One serious help over the last 6 months - the increase in Au price has kept GRL alive - and even if the gold grades are lower than the JORC code states - then the high price keeps it moving forward and even low production can maintain payment to keep the lights on. I do see the company MCAP increasing to £25m+ if they show evidence they can maintain minimum of 400 oz/month and Au over $4500 oz together with planned production improvements. Note - the AISC is currently higher than the gold price was in earlier 2025 - and considering it was suggested to be in $600oz in Dec 2021 - something is seriously wrong. So MCAP £25m if their RNS are true!!

data.author: PaulJ8520
data.content: On the voting proxy thing it says;;; "Use of Proceeds Approximately £1.4 million of the net proceeds of the Subscription will be used to expedite the Company’s exploration programme at the Homase Mine in Ghana, with the objective of expanding and enhancing the current JORC Resource, together with supporting business administration and working capital requirements. The Company plans to use the remaining funds to invest in gold projects outside Ghana, aiming to diversify its asset base and enhance Shareholder value. It is currently in advanced discussions regarding a potential investment in a company with gold assets in Sierra Leone. No binding agreements have been made yet, and the Company will provide further updates if any such agreements are finalised." So not an acquisition. data.author: wasarunner
data.content: Quick maths and so it may be wrong and/or the website info out of date. AIMS: 144m new shares + 249m old shares = 393m shares for their new 29.9999999999999% holding mystery investor: 200m new shares for their 17% ish holding mystery investor converts another 200m new shares, probably 30% shareholding of the enlarged shareholding at that point AIMS convert a few $ accrued interest into shares Presto: the two units hold 60%. You'll know after EGM anyway because at 17% they'll have to declare. Paracle have just about too few shares now that 17%+existing shares wouldn't put them over 30% so it's possible. But my bet is it's (really) AIMS, and when the warrant exercise they own 60% and the show. It's tempting as a trade - but I don't trust EP enough :) good luck those that do!

data.author: wasarunner

data.title: Result of EGM and TVR
data.full_content:
5 Feb 2026 15:03
RNS Number : 9394R
Goldstone Resources Ltd
05 February 2026
5 February 2026
GOLDSTONE RESOURCES LIMITED
("GoldStone" or the "Company")
Result of Extraordinary General Meeting and Total Voting Rights
GoldStone Resources Limited (AIM: GRL) announces that at its Extraordinary General Meeting ("EGM"), held earlier today, all Resolutions set out in the formal Notice of EGM dated 20 January 2026 were duly passed by Shareholders.
As set out in the Company's announcement on 21 January 2026, shareholder approval of the resolutions enables the Company to complete the £2.0 million Subscription. Approximately £1.4 million of the net proceeds will be applied towards expediting exploration activities at the Homase Mine in Ghana and general expenditure, and the Company looks forward to progressing a 4,000-5,000 metre drill programme over the next six months.
Share Issues, Admission and Total Voting Rights
The Company has agreed to issue, in lieu of outstanding fees, 7,000,000 new Ordinary Shares together with one warrant over new Ordinary Shares on the same terms as the warrants issued pursuant to the Subscription (the "Additional Adviser Fee Shares").
Application has been made to the London Stock Exchange for the New Ordinary Shares announced on 21 January 2026 and the Additional Adviser Fee Shares to be admitted to trading on AIM ("Admission"). Admission is expected to become effective at 8.00 a.m. on or around 10 February 2026. The Additional Adviser Fee shares will be issued fully paid and will rank
pari passu
in all respects with the Company's existing Ordinary Shares.
Following Admission, the Company's issued share capital will comprise 1,325,830,114 Ordinary Shares, each with one voting right. The Company does not hold any shares in treasury. Accordingly, the total number of voting rights in the Company will be 1,325,830,114, which shareholders may use as the denominator for the purposes of calculating their interests under the FCA's Disclosure Guidance and Transparency Rules.
Unless otherwise defined herein, all defined terms used in this announcement shall have the meanings ascribed to them in the Company's announcement of 21 January 2026.
ENDS
For further information, please contact:
GoldStone Resources Limited
Emma Priestley
Tel: +44 (0)1534 487 757
Strand Hanson Limited
James Dance / James Bellman
Tel: +44 (0)20 7409 3494
S. P. Angel Corporate Finance LLP
Ewan Leggat / Charlie Bouverat
Tel: +44 (0)20
3470 0501
St Brides Partners Ltd
Ana Ribeiro
Tel: +44 (0)20 7236 1177
goldstone@stbridespartners.co.uk
The information contained within this announcement is deemed by the Company to constitute inside information as stipulated under the Market Abuse Regulation (EU) No. 596/2014 as it forms part of United Kingdom domestic law by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018, as amended by virtue of the Market Abuse (Amendment) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019.
About Goldstone Resources Limited
GoldStone Resources Limited (AIM: GRL) is an AIM quoted mining and development company with projects in Ghana that range from grassroots exploration to production.
The Company is focused on developing the Akrokeri-Homase project in south-western Ghana, which hosts a JORC Code compliant 602,000oz gold resource at an average grade of 1.77 g/t. The existing resource is confined to a 4km zone of the Homase Trend, including Homase North, Homase Pit and Homase South.
The project hosts two former mines, the Akrokerri Ashanti Mine Ltd, which produced 75,000 oz gold at 24 g/t recovered grade in the early 1900s, and the Homase Pit which AngloGold Ashanti developed in 2002/03 producing 52,000 oz gold at 2.5 g/t recovered. Production is currently focussed on the Homase Mine however it is the Company's intention to build a portfolio of high-quality gold projects, with a particular focus on the highly prospective Birimian Gold Belt.

data.title: Operational Update
data.full_content:
4 Feb 2026 07:00
RNS Number : 6002R
Goldstone Resources Ltd
04 February 2026
04 February 2026
GOLDSTONE RESOURCES LIMITED
("Goldstone" or the "Company")
Operational Update
GoldStone Resources Limited (AIM:GRL) (the "Company")
is pleased to provide an operational update.
The Company confirms that gold production has continued into 2026, with a gold pour of approximately
12 kilograms of doré
(equivalent to approximately 385 ounces)
completed at the end of January 2026.
Mining has commenced on the near-surface oxide material from Pit 3 of the Homase Mine. Construction activities at
Pad 6
are progressing as planned, with earthworks completed for the installation of the leak detection pipework and the geofabric and geomembrane installation expected to commence later this month. In parallel, the Company is also preparing drill pad areas to support mine planning activities associated with
Pit 5 and Pit 6
, as part of its ongoing optimisation and forward planning for the mine.
The Company is also undertaking a review of its
Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR)
programme. This review is intended to assess the specific needs and priorities of each local community, with the objective of ensuring engagement is appropriate, effective, and aligned with the Company's operational plans while managing stakeholder expectations.
Emma Priestley, Chief Executive Officer, commented
:
"We are pleased to have started 2026 with continued gold production and a successful doré pour at the end of January. We look forward to providing updates as operations progress, and we are reviewing our CSR programme to ensure our engagement with local communities remains meaningful, transparent, and aligned with both current and anticipated operational realities and community needs"

data.author: GheeBhee
data.content: I also was there and can confirm and elaborate without to much  repetition. The vote was passed on a show of hands, which illustrates the importance of being there if you are serious about involvement. Mr Robinson (possibly as a proxy of Somercourt Investments, his family office)as an existing shareholder was present and joined the discussion. He assured us he is not an insider, knows no more than any of us what the board has in mind for broadening the focus of the company but is supportive nevertheless.  I detected no intention to demand a seventh director but given the gist of his positive intervention I was not inclined to try to pin him down and neither did anyone else.  Given his experience, status and access to analytical support no one here can lay claim to it seems appropriate to get in behind him but that's a personal choice of course.  The two new directors were in the room and appeared engaged but probably rightly did not contribute to the discussion. One has deep Sierra Leone experience, the relevance of which is clear, the other has Ghana experience which will be invaluable given the social desire for change and legislative developments there.  The board met before and after in private and you can read the result for yourself.

data.author: RightOn
data.content: The EGM. I was there (who else??). So let me post my notes from the meeting. I can say one important thing. Bill was not there, and not been mentioned. Neither was Angela present or mentioned. After having attended several AGM’s, this meeting felt different. Rather than explaining the most recent issues, explain away upsets, as most other meetings seemed to do, this meeting came out with a plan. Here are my notes from the meeting: •	Due to issues at the AGM (an ambush from an unfriendly agent, if I understood correctly – I was not present), financing issues could not be properly addressed. They have been in the present EGM. •	The present meeting was organised to put forward and complete the investment attracted to complete the reorganisation and restructure of the company to expedite progress in Ghana. •	The investor (George Robinson – see below) came in at a substantial premium to share price. The confidence in this investment has been confirmed by the rise in share price. •	George Robinson has been an investor since 2017. He is part of a family investment group as well as Sloane Robinson, private investors into the metals industries. I was told that they have been very successful. He was present, and gave a very positive view of his investment. •	We were told that historic local creditors have all now been paid (diesel, cyanide, etc), so the Ghana company is in financial state. •	There is lots of potential from the area surrounding the main pit, and which will be drilled. Stage one will drill approx. 5,000 metres, whilst there will be 16,000 – 18,000 metres to follow. •	We were told that there are approx  600,000ozs of known gold in the ground. This sets Goldstone up for a prospective future if this is maintained.

data.author: JaneMtc
data.content: It’s great news unless you don’t hold and want a lower entry lol The statement refers to a single gold pour of approximately 12 kilograms of doré (a semi-pure alloy, typically mostly gold with some silver and impurities) completed at the end of January 2026, which the company equates to approximately 385 ounces. This is the contained gold content in troy ounces (the standard unit for precious metals). The conversion uses the fact that 1 kilogram ≈ 32.1507 troy ounces, so: - 12 kg × 32.1507 oz/kg ≈ 385.8 troy ounces (rounded to 385 ounces in the statement). Doré bars are not pure gold (often 90–99% gold), but the "equivalent to approximately 385 ounces" specifically means the fine gold content (pure gold weight) in troy ounces, after accounting for the actual purity of that doré pour. Annual Equivalent: The quote describes one pour (for one month, January 2026). To estimate an annual production rate, assuming this pour is representative of monthly output and production continues at a similar pace throughout the year: - 385 ounces per month × 12 months = approximately 4,620 ounces per year. This is a rough extrapolation (actual monthly pours can vary due to processing, ore grades, etc.), but it gives a sense of scale: roughly 4,600–4,700 ounces of gold per year if sustained at that level.

data.author: Fr.Jack.Hackett
data.content: Mr 05, ". . could you please tell me why you are invested in Goldstone resources. . ", sorry - I do not join in such irrelevant discussion. I am interested in GRL based on their historic RNS statements going back to 2019/2020. Please read - especially the ones released throughout 2022 - they make as good reading as the script to faulty towers. Prospects going forward! - wonderful if you believe even half the wording in the RNS !! The use of the word "believe" in that statement is the main issue. If gold grades are there (and I have doubts) - then I am sure the Homase mine can be profitable (if no debt attached - such as the gold loan). One serious help over the last 6 months - the increase in Au price has kept GRL alive - and even if the gold grades are lower than the JORC code states - then the high price keeps it moving forward and even low production can maintain payment to keep the lights on. I do see the company MCAP increasing to £25m+ if they show evidence they can maintain minimum of 400 oz/month and Au over $4500 oz together with planned production improvements. Note - the AISC is currently higher than the gold price was in earlier 2025 - and considering it was suggested to be in $600oz in Dec 2021 - something is seriously wrong. This risk shall be with this company until it at least halves the AISC. I also think GRL are struggling to keep AISC even at the higher limit of the range based on lack of detail/evidence they have provided - every forward statement they have released in RNS since 2020 - have been followed later by the actual performance figures being magnitures worst. So MCAP £25m if their RNS are true!!

data.author: PaulJ8520
data.content: On the voting proxy thing it says;;; "Use of Proceeds Approximately £1.4 million of the net proceeds of the Subscription will be used to expedite the Company’s exploration programme at the Homase Mine in Ghana, with the objective of expanding and enhancing the current JORC Resource, together with supporting business administration and working capital requirements. The Company plans to use the remaining funds to invest in gold projects outside Ghana, aiming to diversify its asset base and enhance Shareholder value. It is currently in advanced discussions regarding a potential investment in a company with gold assets in Sierra Leone. No binding agreements have been made yet, and the Company will provide further updates if any such agreements are finalised." So not an acquisition. I'd rather have the remaining ploughed into Homase, but I couldn't vote on that, such a shame. Does it mean they think they have enough funds coming in from Homase to continue expansion? I wonder!

data.author: booboouberbear
data.content: 1nvest, It's abundantly clear last year H2 has seen a meltdown in stacking. Why was this? Skill? CAPEX issues? Rain? Regulatory Inspections? All 4? But if / when they sort it out, there is capacity here with existing infrastructure on the ground to stack 672k tonnes and produce circa 14k troy ounces. I make that somewhere in the region of 5 to 10p a share if you can get AISCs at $2.5k an ounce. It's always been an insane risk v reward proposition here, and its getting less and less risky.

data.author: wasarunner
data.content: Quick maths and so it may be wrong and/or the website info out of date. AIMS: 144m new shares + 249m old shares = 393m shares for their new 29.9999999999999% holding mystery investor: 200m new shares for their 17% ish holding mystery investor converts another 200m new shares, probably 30% shareholding of the enlarged shareholding at that point AIMS convert a few $ accrued interest into shares Presto: the two units hold 60%. You'll know after EGM anyway because at 17% they'll have to declare. Paracle have just about too few shares now that 17%+existing shares wouldn't put them over 30% so it's possible. But my bet is it's (really) AIMS, and when the warrant exercise they own 60% and the show. It's tempting as a trade - but I don't trust EP enough :) good luck those that do!

data.title: Directorate change
data.full_content:
Today 18:24
RNS Number : 3182S
Goldstone Resources Ltd
09 February 2026
9 February 2026
GOLDSTONE RESOURCES LIMITED
("GoldStone" or the "Company")
Directorate Change
GoldStone Resources Limited (AIM: GRL) announces that Mr Richard Wilkins is stepping down from his role as an Independent Non-Executive Director of the Company, with immediate effect.
Emma Priestley, Chief Executive Officer, commented:
"The Board would like to thank Richard for his dedication and hard work in guiding GoldStone through the past few years. His efforts have been greatly appreciated."
ENDS
For further information, please contact:
GoldStone Resources Limited
Emma Priestley
Tel: +44 (0)1534 487 757
Strand Hanson Limited
James Dance / James Bellman
Tel: +44 (0)20 7409 3494

Ewan Leggat / Charlie Bouverat
Tel: +44 (0)20
3470 0501
St Brides Partners Ltd
Ana Ribeiro
Tel: +44 (0)20 7236 1177
goldstone@stbridespartners.co.uk
The information contained within this announcement is deemed by the Company to constitute inside information as stipulated under the Market Abuse Regulation (EU) No. 596/2014 as it forms part of United Kingdom domestic law by virtue of the European Union (Withdrawal) Act 2018, as amended by virtue of the Market Abuse (Amendment) (EU Exit) Regulations 2019.
About Goldstone Resources Limited
GoldStone Resources Limited (AIM: GRL) is an AIM quoted mining and development company with projects in Ghana that range from grassroots exploration to production.
The Company is focused on developing the Akrokeri-Homase project in south-western Ghana, which hosts a JORC Code compliant 602,000oz gold resource at an average grade of 1.77 g/t. The existing resource is confined to a 4km zone of the Homase Trend, including Homase North, Homase Pit and Homase South.
The project hosts two former mines, the Akrokerri Ashanti Mine Ltd, which produced 75,000 oz gold at 24 g/t recovered grade in the early 1900s, and the Homase Pit which AngloGold Ashanti developed in 2002/03 producing 52,000 oz gold at 2.5 g/t recovered. Production is currently focussed on the Homase Mine however it is the Company's intention to build a portfolio of high-quality gold projects, with a particular focus on the highly prospective Birimian Gold Belt.

data.author: Antibacterial
data.content: Phoenix Copper Limited (AIM: PXC; OTCQX ADR: PXCLY), the AIM quoted, 100% USA focused base and precious metals emerging producer and exploration company, announces that the Board has resolved to suspend Marcus Edwards-Jones and Richard Wilkins from their roles as Executive Chairman and Chief Financial Officer and Company Secretary, respectively, with immediate effect. The Company's Board has commenced investigations into allegations made in relation to Mr Edwards-Jones's and Mr Wilkins's recent conduct and certain historic payments made to Lloyd Edwards-Jones S.A.S., the Company's former Corporate Finance Adviser. The investigations are being undertaken with input from the Company's professional advisers and a further announcement will be made as soon as these investigations have concluded. To minimise any disruption to the ongoing operations of the Company during the period of Mr Edwards-Jones's and Mr Wilkins's suspension, the Company has put interim financial oversight arrangements in place while it advances the appointment of an interim CFO. This interim role will be covered until such time as Mr Wilkins's and Mr Edwards-Jones's suspension is over and a conclusion has been reached on the outcome of the investigation. The individual concerned will be supported by Catherine Evans, Chair of the Audit Committee and Ryan McDermott, CEO, as well as by other members of the Board and senior management team to ensure operational continuity.

data.author: GheeBhee
data.content: I also was there and can confirm and elaborate without to much  repetition. The vote was passed on a show of hands, which illustrates the importance of being there if you are serious about involvement. Mr Robinson (possibly as a proxy of Somercourt Investments, his family office)as an existing shareholder was present and joined the discussion. He assured us he is not an insider, knows no more than any of us what the board has in mind for broadening the focus of the company but is supportive nevertheless.  I detected no intention to demand a seventh director but given the gist of his positive intervention I was not inclined to try to pin him down and neither did anyone else.  Given his experience, status and access to analytical support no one here can lay claim to it seems appropriate to get in behind him but that's a personal choice of course.  The two new directors were in the room and appeared engaged but probably rightly did not contribute to the discussion. One has deep Sierra Leone experience, the relevance of which is clear, the other has Ghana experience which will be invaluable given the social desire for change and legislative developments there.  The board met before and after in private and you can read the result for yourself.

data.author: RightOn
data.content: The EGM. I was there (who else??). So let me post my notes from the meeting. I can say one important thing. Bill was not there, and not been mentioned. Neither was Angela present or mentioned. After having attended several AGM’s, this meeting felt different. Rather than explaining the most recent issues, explain away upsets, as most other meetings seemed to do, this meeting came out with a plan. Here are my notes from the meeting: •	Due to issues at the AGM (an ambush from an unfriendly agent, if I understood correctly – I was not present), financing issues could not be properly addressed. They have been in the present EGM. •	The present meeting was organised to put forward and complete the investment attracted to complete the reorganisation and restructure of the company to expedite progress in Ghana. •	The investor (George Robinson – see below) came in at a substantial premium to share price. The confidence in this investment has been confirmed by the rise in share price. •	George Robinson has been an investor since 2017. He is part of a family investment group as well as Sloane Robinson, private investors into the metals industries. I was told that they have been very successful. He was present, and gave a very positive view of his investment. •	We were told that historic local creditors have all now been paid (diesel, cyanide, etc), so the Ghana company is in financial state. •	There is lots of potential from the area surrounding the main pit, and which will be drilled. Stage one will drill approx. 5,000 metres, whilst there will be 16,000 – 18,000 metres to follow. •	We were told that there are approx  600,000ozs of known gold in the ground. This sets Goldstone up for a prospective future if this is maintained.

data.author: JaneMtc
data.content: It’s great news unless you don’t hold and want a lower entry lol The statement refers to a single gold pour of approximately 12 kilograms of doré (a semi-pure alloy, typically mostly gold with some silver and impurities) completed at the end of January 2026, which the company equates to approximately 385 ounces. This is the contained gold content in troy ounces (the standard unit for precious metals). The conversion uses the fact that 1 kilogram ≈ 32.1507 troy ounces, so: - 12 kg × 32.1507 oz/kg ≈ 385.8 troy ounces (rounded to 385 ounces in the statement). Doré bars are not pure gold (often 90–99% gold), but the "equivalent to approximately 385 ounces" specifically means the fine gold content (pure gold weight) in troy ounces, after accounting for the actual purity of that doré pour. Annual Equivalent: The quote describes one pour (for one month, January 2026). To estimate an annual production rate, assuming this pour is representative of monthly output and production continues at a similar pace throughout the year: - 385 ounces per month × 12 months = approximately 4,620 ounces per year. This is a rough extrapolation (actual monthly pours can vary due to processing, ore grades, etc.), but it gives a sense of scale: roughly 4,600–4,700 ounces of gold per year if sustained at that level.

data.author: Fr.Jack.Hackett
data.content: Mr 05, ". . could you please tell me why you are invested in Goldstone resources. . ", sorry - I do not join in such irrelevant discussion. I am interested in GRL based on their historic RNS statements going back to 2019/2020. Please read - especially the ones released throughout 2022 - they make as good reading as the script to faulty towers. Prospects going forward! - wonderful if you believe even half the wording in the RNS !! The use of the word "believe" in that statement is the main issue. If gold grades are there (and I have doubts) - then I am sure the Homase mine can be profitable (if no debt attached - such as the gold loan). One serious help over the last 6 months - the increase in Au price has kept GRL alive - and even if the gold grades are lower than the JORC code states - then the high price keeps it moving forward and even low production can maintain payment to keep the lights on. I do see the company MCAP increasing to £25m+ if they show evidence they can maintain minimum of 400 oz/month and Au over $4500 oz together with planned production improvements. Note - the AISC is currently higher than the gold price was in earlier 2025 - and considering it was suggested to be in $600oz in Dec 2021 - something is seriously wrong. This risk shall be with this company until it at least halves the AISC. I also think GRL are struggling to keep AISC even at the higher limit of the range based on lack of detail/evidence they have provided - every forward statement they have released in RNS since 2020 - have been followed later by the actual performance figures being magnitures worst. So MCAP £25m if their RNS are true!!

data.author: PaulJ8520
data.content: On the voting proxy thing it says;;; "Use of Proceeds Approximately £1.4 million of the net proceeds of the Subscription will be used to expedite the Company’s exploration programme at the Homase Mine in Ghana, with the objective of expanding and enhancing the current JORC Resource, together with supporting business administration and working capital requirements. The Company plans to use the remaining funds to invest in gold projects outside Ghana, aiming to diversify its asset base and enhance Shareholder value. It is currently in advanced discussions regarding a potential investment in a company with gold assets in Sierra Leone. No binding agreements have been made yet, and the Company will provide further updates if any such agreements are finalised." So not an acquisition. I'd rather have the remaining ploughed into Homase, but I couldn't vote on that, such a shame. Does it mean they think they have enough funds coming in from Homase to continue expansion? I wonder!

data.author: Antibacterial
data.content: Phoenix Copper Limited (AIM: PXC; OTCQX ADR: PXCLY), the AIM quoted, 100% USA focused base and precious metals emerging producer and exploration company, announces that the Board has resolved to suspend Marcus Edwards-Jones and Richard Wilkins from their roles as Executive Chairman and Chief Financial Officer and Company Secretary, respectively, with immediate effect. The Company's Board has commenced investigations into allegations made in relation to Mr Edwards-Jones's and Mr Wilkins's recent conduct and certain historic payments made to Lloyd Edwards-Jones S.A.S., the Company's former Corporate Finance Adviser. The investigations are being undertaken with input from the Company's professional advisers and a further announcement will be made as soon as these investigations have concluded. To minimise any disruption to the ongoing operations of the Company during the period of Mr Edwards-Jones's and Mr Wilkins's suspension, the Company has put interim financial oversight arrangements in place while it advances the appointment of an interim CFO. This interim role will be covered until such time as Mr Wilkins's and Mr Edwards-Jones's suspension is over and a conclusion has been reached on the outcome of the investigation. The individual concerned will be supported by Catherine Evans, Chair of the Audit Committee and Ryan McDermott, CEO, as well as by other members of the Board and senior management team to ensure operational continuity.

data.author: GheeBhee
data.content: I also was there and can confirm and elaborate without to much  repetition. The vote was passed on a show of hands, which illustrates the importance of being there if you are serious about involvement. Mr Robinson (possibly as a proxy of Somercourt Investments, his family office)as an existing shareholder was present and joined the discussion. He assured us he is not an insider, knows no more than any of us what the board has in mind for broadening the focus of the company but is supportive nevertheless.  I detected no intention to demand a seventh director but given the gist of his positive intervention I was not inclined to try to pin him down and neither did anyone else.  Given his experience, status and access to analytical support no one here can lay claim to it seems appropriate to get in behind him but that's a personal choice of course.  The two new directors were in the room and appeared engaged but probably rightly did not contribute to the discussion. One has deep Sierra Leone experience, the relevance of which is clear, the other has Ghana experience which will be invaluable given the social desire for change and legislative developments there.  The board met before and after in private and you can read the result for yourself.

data.author: RightOn
data.content: The EGM. I was there (who else??). So let me post my notes from the meeting. I can say one important thing. Bill was not there, and not been mentioned. Neither was Angela present or mentioned. After having attended several AGM’s, this meeting felt different. Rather than explaining the most recent issues, explain away upsets, as most other meetings seemed to do, this meeting came out with a plan. Here are my notes from the meeting: •	Due to issues at the AGM (an ambush from an unfriendly agent, if I understood correctly – I was not present), financing issues could not be properly addressed. They have been in the present EGM. •	The present meeting was organised to put forward and complete the investment attracted to complete the reorganisation and restructure of the company to expedite progress in Ghana. •	The investor (George Robinson – see below) came in at a substantial premium to share price. The confidence in this investment has been confirmed by the rise in share price. •	George Robinson has been an investor since 2017. He is part of a family investment group as well as Sloane Robinson, private investors into the metals industries. I was told that they have been very successful. He was present, and gave a very positive view of his investment. •	We were told that historic local creditors have all now been paid (diesel, cyanide, etc), so the Ghana company is in financial state. •	There is lots of potential from the area surrounding the main pit, and which will be drilled. Stage one will drill approx. 5,000 metres, whilst there will be 16,000 – 18,000 metres to follow. •	We were told that there are approx  600,000ozs of known gold in the ground. This sets Goldstone up for a prospective future if this is maintained.

data.author: JaneMtc
data.content: It’s great news unless you don’t hold and want a lower entry lol The statement refers to a single gold pour of approximately 12 kilograms of doré (a semi-pure alloy, typically mostly gold with some silver and impurities) completed at the end of January 2026, which the company equates to approximately 385 ounces. This is the contained gold content in troy ounces (the standard unit for precious metals). The conversion uses the fact that 1 kilogram ≈ 32.1507 troy ounces, so: - 12 kg × 32.1507 oz/kg ≈ 385.8 troy ounces (rounded to 385 ounces in the statement). Doré bars are not pure gold (often 90–99% gold), but the "equivalent to approximately 385 ounces" specifically means the fine gold content (pure gold weight) in troy ounces, after accounting for the actual purity of that doré pour. Annual Equivalent: The quote describes one pour (for one month, January 2026). To estimate an annual production rate, assuming this pour is representative of monthly output and production continues at a similar pace throughout the year: - 385 ounces per month × 12 months = approximately 4,620 ounces per year. This is a rough extrapolation (actual monthly pours can vary due to processing, ore grades, etc.), but it gives a sense of scale: roughly 4,600–4,700 ounces of gold per year if sustained at that level.

data.author: Fr.Jack.Hackett
data.content: Mr 05, ". . could you please tell me why you are invested in Goldstone resources. . ", sorry - I do not join in such irrelevant discussion. I am interested in GRL based on their historic RNS statements going back to 2019/2020. Please read - especially the ones released throughout 2022 - they make as good reading as the script to faulty towers. Prospects going forward! - wonderful if you believe even half the wording in the RNS !! The use of the word "believe" in that statement is the main issue. If gold grades are there (and I have doubts) - then I am sure the Homase mine can be profitable (if no debt attached - such as the gold loan). One serious help over the last 6 months - the increase in Au price has kept GRL alive - and even if the gold grades are lower than the JORC code states - then the high price keeps it moving forward and even low production can maintain payment to keep the lights on. I do see the company MCAP increasing to £25m+ if they show evidence they can maintain minimum of 400 oz/month and Au over $4500 oz together with planned production improvements. Note - the AISC is currently higher than the gold price was in earlier 2025 - and considering it was suggested to be in $600oz in Dec 2021 - something is seriously wrong. This risk shall be with this company until it at least halves the AISC. I also think GRL are struggling to keep AISC even at the higher limit of the range based on lack of detail/evidence they have provided - every forward statement they have released in RNS since 2020 - have been followed later by the actual performance figures being magnitures worst. So MCAP £25m if their RNS are true!!

data.author: PaulJ8520
data.content: On the voting proxy thing it says;;; "Use of Proceeds Approximately £1.4 million of the net proceeds of the Subscription will be used to expedite the Company’s exploration programme at the Homase Mine in Ghana, with the objective of expanding and enhancing the current JORC Resource, together with supporting business administration and working capital requirements. The Company plans to use the remaining funds to invest in gold projects outside Ghana, aiming to diversify its asset base and enhance Shareholder value. It is currently in advanced discussions regarding a potential investment in a company with gold assets in Sierra Leone. No binding agreements have been made yet, and the Company will provide further updates if any such agreements are finalised." So not an acquisition. I'd rather have the remaining ploughed into Homase, but I couldn't vote on that, such a shame. Does it mean they think they have enough funds coming in from Homase to continue expansion? I wonder!

data.author: booboouberbear
data.content: 1nvest, It's abundantly clear last year H2 has seen a meltdown in stacking. Why was this? Skill? CAPEX issues? Rain? Regulatory Inspections? All 4? But if / when they sort it out, there is capacity here with existing infrastructure on the ground to stack 672k tonnes and produce circa 14k troy ounces. I make that somewhere in the region of 5 to 10p a share if you can get AISCs at $2.5k an ounce. It's always been an insane risk v reward proposition here, and its getting less and less risky.

data.author: banjomick
data.content: A reminder from the last RNS and yes I take fully on-board the lack of 'targets' being met over the years but GRL in their current form are a relatively new company going from exploration to producer: "We are pleased to have conditionally raised £2.0 million, which strengthens the Company's balance sheet and provides funding to accelerate exploration at the Homase Mine while also enabling us to consider additional opportunities beyond our core asset. The support shown through the subscription, together with the conversion of debt and fees into equity, demonstrates continued alignment with shareholders as we advance the Company's growth strategy."

data.author: banjomick
data.content: Hi ID, got rained off from gardening work, horrible out there! I know you asked boo but I to would expect an improvement in gold production from the next update for a few reasons: 1. It's the dry season now, therefore no delays from rainfall 2.  "A new screening and conveying system was completed and commissioned in December 2025, enabling stacking rates of up to 56,000 tonnes of agglomerated ore per month, providing increased operational flexibility." That's obviously depending on whether it's on-line and working after commissioning! 3. "The mining schedule has been restructured to maximise production during drier operational periods" 4. With the new board now settled in, by the sounds of it overseeing day to day activities, along with lessons learnt and the experience gained over the last two years or so, should make the whole process more efficient yielding greater gold production..........in theory! :-)

Choose to buy my view or not, but I was right with the gold loan, right with the share reconstruction, and I'll be right with this too. Only time will prove me right of course.

data.author: Iceman_1
data.content: What a great start to the week!!! 🔥 This RNS is exactly the type of news that typically re-rates a small AIM mining stock:- Contractor signed = Execution underway No longer plans, this is action. Kuboc isn’t just engaged — it’s mobilising. Mining timeline now defined A February start gives the market a clear near-term event to price in. Revenue visibility beginning With first sales expected this quarter, NTVO is on the verge of moving toward cash flow — the key value driver. Scale-up potential The production targets grow over time, which means higher throughput and potentially more gold sold as the mine ramps. We’re now on a clear upward trajectory. What you’re seeing is a re-rate as the company transitions from explorer → producer.

data.author: wasarunner
data.content: Quick maths and so it may be wrong and/or the website info out of date. AIMS: 144m new shares + 249m old shares = 393m shares for their new 29.9999999999999% holding mystery investor: 200m new shares for their 17% ish holding mystery investor converts another 200m new shares, probably 30% shareholding of the enlarged shareholding at that point AIMS convert a few $ accrued interest into shares Presto: the two units hold 60%. You'll know after EGM anyway because at 17% they'll have to declare. Paracle have just about too few shares now that 17%+existing shares wouldn't put them over 30% so it's possible. But my bet is it's (really) AIMS, and when the warrant exercise they own 60% and the show. It's tempting as a trade - but I don't trust EP enough :) good luck those that do!

data.author: wasarunner
data.content: Well if it helps - as we approached year end I considered buying a few because the company seemed in a paradox - as a trader, I think it made sense to buy (on the chance that, as they've done, stay of execution). It was priced to fail. I would only have put a small amount in and, being not a trader, in the end didn't. It was obvious even the stay of execution would get a rerate with any better news a bigger rerate. These are the events traders look for which is why they come in before/after news to try and pump it Instead I put my money elsewhere and I hope it works out - I went asx/psl where they're drilling next to Greatlands plot. Hopefully it works out. I remain very bullish on gold (this is my first gold divestment since GRL debarcle), very bearish on EP here, but as always, I hope you guys win, it sucks to lose, I wouldn't wish it on anyone. What we can all agree on long may the price of gold rise, and I don't think there's that much chance of a reversal with the Big Orange in charge over the pond. GLA

data.author: booboouberbear
data.content: To be fair, more than one thing can be correct at once, this company has a history, that amongst other things has seen its diluted share price fall by some 99%, its been a terrible investment up to this point. AIMS / Paracle, and whomever else ponied up this cash obviously think its a good investment, and believe EP is the person to lead it, their information will be better than ours. data.author: banjomick
data.content: The 2025 'targets' were a obviously long way off being achieved and this was reflected in the decline in SP through the year as it became clear they were never going to be met although I thought they might have improved! Not helped by in-house company issues either! The 'targets' have been lowered for this year which are now more or less the same level as 2022 and that's with all the new machinery in place along with other plant enhancements ! I believe a lot of the under performing is mainly due to : 1. GRL are operating a very small scale mining operation (one step up from actually panning for gold) where the slightest issue is detrimental to gold production 2. A lack of experience by GRL management in actually running a very small scale mining operation as their 2025 'targets' prove 3. The rainy season does affect production in a big way and especially with the size of this operation 4. In-house company issues but hopefully all now resolved with a stronger more focused team! Therefore with recent further improvements to plant now in place and the experience gained over the last few years I am expecting a better year for both the company and the SP....he says bravely or stupidly before anyone says it!  :-) 5 February 2026 -"and the Company looks forward to progressing a 4,000-5,000 metre drill programme over the next six months." An update regarding this is called for as it reads like one of last years 'targets' as in I look forward to winning the lottery every week!

data.author: Kennyp52
data.content: Bill .. answer me this .. if targets are not justifiable then do they then become lies ? In May 2023 this was released .. Gold Production To date, some 220,000 tonnes of oxide ore @ 1.43g/t has been mined and stacked on the heap leach pads. This has yielded contained gold of some 10,956 ounces of gold. The Company has, to date, recovered and sold some 5,403 ounces of gold, with the remaining contained gold, estimated to be 5,553 ounces, still within the pads. The Company is assessing the economics of re-agglomerating this ore on the heap leach pads, as insufficient cement was added and this needs to be remediated. You was there .. what happened to the 5,553 ounces ? At the time I think it was Troy rather than dore ?? How can you explain this proven production back then when further plant etc. has been added and we go backwards to a 4,000 Oz target which I think now is dore weight ? 48,000t of ore stacking at over 1g/t - simply does not add up You have questions to answer also imho.

data.author: Antibacterial
data.content: Phoenix Copper Limited (AIM: PXC; OTCQX ADR: PXCLY), the AIM quoted, 100% USA focused base and precious metals emerging producer and exploration company, announces that the Board has resolved to suspend Marcus Edwards-Jones and Richard Wilkins from their roles as Executive Chairman and Chief Financial Officer and Company Secretary, respectively, with immediate effect. The Company's Board has commenced investigations into allegations made in relation to Mr Edwards-Jones's and Mr Wilkins's recent conduct and certain historic payments made to Lloyd Edwards-Jones S.A.S., the Company's former Corporate Finance Adviser. The investigations are being undertaken with input from the Company's professional advisers and a further announcement will be made as soon as these investigations have concluded. To minimise any disruption to the ongoing operations of the Company during the period of Mr Edwards-Jones's and Mr Wilkins's suspension, the Company has put interim financial oversight arrangements in place while it advances the appointment of an interim CFO. This interim role will be covered until such time as Mr Wilkins's and Mr Edwards-Jones's suspension is over and a conclusion has been reached on the outcome of the investigation. The individual concerned will be supported by Catherine Evans, Chair of the Audit Committee and Ryan McDermott, CEO, as well as by other members of the Board and senior management team to ensure operational continuity.

data.author: GheeBhee
data.content: I also was there and can confirm and elaborate without to much  repetition. The vote was passed on a show of hands, which illustrates the importance of being there if you are serious about involvement. Mr Robinson (possibly as a proxy of Somercourt Investments, his family office)as an existing shareholder was present and joined the discussion. He assured us he is not an insider, knows no more than any of us what the board has in mind for broadening the focus of the company but is supportive nevertheless.  I detected no intention to demand a seventh director but given the gist of his positive intervention I was not inclined to try to pin him down and neither did anyone else.  Given his experience, status and access to analytical support no one here can lay claim to it seems appropriate to get in behind him but that's a personal choice of course.  The two new directors were in the room and appeared engaged but probably rightly did not contribute to the discussion. One has deep Sierra Leone experience, the relevance of which is clear, the other has Ghana experience which will be invaluable given the social desire for change and legislative developments there.  The board met before and after in private and you can read the result for yourself.

data.author: RightOn
data.content: The EGM. I was there (who else??). So let me post my notes from the meeting. I can say one important thing. Bill was not there, and not been mentioned. Neither was Angela present or mentioned. After having attended several AGM’s, this meeting felt different. Rather than explaining the most recent issues, explain away upsets, as most other meetings seemed to do, this meeting came out with a plan. Here are my notes from the meeting: •	Due to issues at the AGM (an ambush from an unfriendly agent, if I understood correctly – I was not present), financing issues could not be properly addressed. They have been in the present EGM. •	The present meeting was organised to put forward and complete the investment attracted to complete the reorganisation and restructure of the company to expedite progress in Ghana. •	The investor (George Robinson – see below) came in at a substantial premium to share price. The confidence in this investment has been confirmed by the rise in share price. •	George Robinson has been an investor since 2017. He is part of a family investment group as well as Sloane Robinson, private investors into the metals industries. I was told that they have been very successful. He was present, and gave a very positive view of his investment. •	We were told that historic local creditors have all now been paid (diesel, cyanide, etc), so the Ghana company is in financial state. •	There is lots of potential from the area surrounding the main pit, and which will be drilled. Stage one will drill approx. 5,000 metres, whilst there will be 16,000 – 18,000 metres to follow. •	We were told that there are approx  600,000ozs of known gold in the ground. This sets Goldstone up for a prospective future if this is maintained.

data.author: JaneMtc
data.content: It’s great news unless you don’t hold and want a lower entry lol The statement refers to a single gold pour of approximately 12 kilograms of doré (a semi-pure alloy, typically mostly gold with some silver and impurities) completed at the end of January 2026, which the company equates to approximately 385 ounces. This is the contained gold content in troy ounces (the standard unit for precious metals). The conversion uses the fact that 1 kilogram ≈ 32.1507 troy ounces, so: - 12 kg × 32.1507 oz/kg ≈ 385.8 troy ounces (rounded to 385 ounces in the statement). Doré bars are not pure gold (often 90–99% gold), but the "equivalent to approximately 385 ounces" specifically means the fine gold content (pure gold weight) in troy ounces, after accounting for the actual purity of that doré pour. Annual Equivalent: The quote describes one pour (for one month, January 2026). To estimate an annual production rate, assuming this pour is representative of monthly output and production continues at a similar pace throughout the year: - 385 ounces per month × 12 months = approximately 4,620 ounces per year. This is a rough extrapolation (actual monthly pours can vary due to processing, ore grades, etc.), but it gives a sense of scale: roughly 4,600–4,700 ounces of gold per year if sustained at that level.

data.author: Fr.Jack.Hackett
data.content: Mr 05, ". . could you please tell me why you are invested in Goldstone resources. . ", sorry - I do not join in such irrelevant discussion. I am interested in GRL based on their historic RNS statements going back to 2019/2020. Please read - especially the ones released throughout 2022 - they make as good reading as the script to faulty towers. Prospects going forward! - wonderful if you believe even half the wording in the RNS !! The use of the word "believe" in that statement is the main issue. If gold grades are there (and I have doubts) - then I am sure the Homase mine can be profitable (if no debt attached - such as the gold loan). One serious help over the last 6 months - the increase in Au price has kept GRL alive - and even if the gold grades are lower than the JORC code states - then the high price keeps it moving forward and even low production can maintain payment to keep the lights on. I do see the company MCAP increasing to £25m+ if they show evidence they can maintain minimum of 400 oz/month and Au over $4500 oz together with planned production improvements. Note - the AISC is currently higher than the gold price was in earlier 2025 - and considering it was suggested to be in $600oz in Dec 2021 - something is seriously wrong. This risk shall be with this company until it at least halves the AISC. I also think GRL are struggling to keep AISC even at the higher limit of the range based on lack of detail/evidence they have provided - every forward statement they have released in RNS since 2020 - have been followed later by the actual performance figures being magnitures worst. So MCAP £25m if their RNS are true!!

data.author: PaulJ8520
data.content: On the voting proxy thing it says;;; "Use of Proceeds Approximately £1.4 million of the net proceeds of the Subscription will be used to expedite the Company’s exploration programme at the Homase Mine in Ghana, with the objective of expanding and enhancing the current JORC Resource, together with supporting business administration and working capital requirements. The Company plans to use the remaining funds to invest in gold projects outside Ghana, aiming to diversify its asset base and enhance Shareholder value. It is currently in advanced discussions regarding a potential investment in a company with gold assets in Sierra Leone. No binding agreements have been made yet, and the Company will provide further updates if any such agreements are finalised." So not an acquisition. I'd rather have the remaining ploughed into Homase, but I couldn't vote on that, such a shame. Does it mean they think they have enough funds coming in from Homase to continue expansion? I wonder!

data.author: booboouberbear
data.content: 1nvest, It's abundantly clear last year H2 has seen a meltdown in stacking. Why was this? Skill? CAPEX issues? Rain? Regulatory Inspections? All 4? But if / when they sort it out, there is capacity here with existing infrastructure on the ground to stack 672k tonnes and produce circa 14k troy ounces. I make that somewhere in the region of 5 to 10p a share if you can get AISCs at $2.5k an ounce. It's always been an insane risk v reward proposition here, and its getting less and less risky.

data.author: banjomick
data.content: A reminder from the last RNS and yes I take fully on-board the lack of 'targets' being met over the years but GRL in their current form are a relatively new company going from exploration to producer: "We are pleased to have conditionally raised £2.0 million, which strengthens the Company's balance sheet and provides funding to accelerate exploration at the Homase Mine while also enabling us to consider additional opportunities beyond our core asset. The support shown through the subscription, together with the conversion of debt and fees into equity, demonstrates continued alignment with shareholders as we advance the Company's growth strategy."

data.author: 1nvest
data.content: Would generally agree the production figures should be smashed but last quarter results were terrible. We even had confirmation prior to this that that they were stacking at 48,000 tonnes a month but not the resulting gold expected. Fingers crossed

data.author: banjomick
data.content: Hi ID, got rained off from gardening work, horrible out there! I know you asked boo but I to would expect an improvement in gold production from the next update for a few reasons: 1. It's the dry season now, therefore no delays from rainfall 2.  "A new screening and conveying system was completed and commissioned in December 2025, enabling stacking rates of up to 56,000 tonnes of agglomerated ore per month, providing increased operational flexibility." That's obviously depending on whether it's on-line and working after commissioning! 3. "The mining schedule has been restructured to maximise production during drier operational periods" 4. With the new board now settled in, by the sounds of it overseeing day to day activities, along with lessons learnt and the experience gained over the last two years or so, should make the whole process more efficient yielding greater gold production..........in theory! :-)

data.author: Corrumpo
data.content: Booboouberbear  I love your optimism, and I sincerely hope you’re right, as I have some way to go to break even. A word of caution though. I’ve seen so many false dawns with this outfit. Remember  corporate investors putting in chunks at 8p or something? We all expected they must know something and went with it. Now people are getting fizzy b*lls over 1.5p Remember Bill Trew saying they should do 28,000oz for the year? Remember EP blatantly lying that GRl was on course for 1000oz a month from Jan ‘25? I hope it goes ballistic, but I think you can only ever have a very modest level in trust in anything this board of directors says.

data.author: booboouberbear
data.content: In the dry season, they need only stack 15k tonnes per month at 68% recovery at 1g/t. They're going to cruise by that. Double, maybe even treble it while the weather is hot and dry (last month of weather has been hot and dry) and with a 54k tonne stacking capacity. Q1 will be a bumper. Choose to buy my view or not, but I was right with the gold loan, right with the share reconstruction, and I'll be right with this too. Only time will prove me right of course.

data.author: Iceman_1
data.content: What a great start to the week!!! 🔥 This RNS is exactly the type of news that typically re-rates a small AIM mining stock:- Contractor signed = Execution underway No longer plans, this is action. Kuboc isn’t just engaged — it’s mobilising. Mining timeline now defined A February start gives the market a clear near-term event to price in. Revenue visibility beginning With first sales expected this quarter, NTVO is on the verge of moving toward cash flow — the key value driver. Scale-up potential The production targets grow over time, which means higher throughput and potentially more gold sold as the mine ramps. We’re now on a clear upward trajectory. What you’re seeing is a re-rate as the company transitions from explorer → producer.

data.author: wasarunner
data.content: Quick maths and so it may be wrong and/or the website info out of date. AIMS: 144m new shares + 249m old shares = 393m shares for their new 29.9999999999999% holding mystery investor: 200m new shares for their 17% ish holding mystery investor converts another 200m new shares, probably 30% shareholding of the enlarged shareholding at that point AIMS convert a few $ accrued interest into shares Presto: the two units hold 60%. You'll know after EGM anyway because at 17% they'll have to declare. Paracle have just about too few shares now that 17%+existing shares wouldn't put them over 30% so it's possible. But my bet is it's (really) AIMS, and when the warrant exercise they own 60% and the show. It's tempting as a trade - but I don't trust EP enough :) good luck those that do!

data.author: wasarunner
data.content: Well if it helps - as we approached year end I considered buying a few because the company seemed in a paradox - as a trader, I think it made sense to buy (on the chance that, as they've done, stay of execution). It was priced to fail. I would only have put a small amount in and, being not a trader, in the end didn't. It was obvious even the stay of execution would get a rerate with any better news a bigger rerate. These are the events traders look for which is why they come in before/after news to try and pump it Instead I put my money elsewhere and I hope it works out - I went asx/psl where they're drilling next to Greatlands plot. Hopefully it works out. I remain very bullish on gold (this is my first gold divestment since GRL debarcle), very bearish on EP here, but as always, I hope you guys win, it sucks to lose, I wouldn't wish it on anyone. What we can all agree on long may the price of gold rise, and I don't think there's that much chance of a reversal with the Big Orange in charge over the pond. GLA

data.author: booboouberbear
data.content: It has to be Paracle or associates, otherwise they'd block the AGM, like they did in August. The 2 new NEDs, where part of the deal that AIMS and Paracle reached over oversight of the company that Paracle wanted. They are Paracle appointees IMO. AIMS has always rebuffed owning more than 30%...even this round of refinancing they've made sure no breach of 30% is done (gone deliberately to 29.9%). As for EP admitted that 3k oz is the limit here in that interview...complete twaddle. She said "look, we are limited by what the plant can do". 1p incoming, and multiples if they confirm stacking in the dry weather is 30k plus per month, as grades and recoveries mean thos is mental cheap for a gold producer. DYOR. Don't believe anyone here, especially me. ATB.

data.author: booboouberbear
data.content: To be fair, more than one thing can be correct at once, this company has a history, that amongst other things has seen its diluted share price fall by some 99%, its been a terrible investment up to this point. That's the problem with mega high risk, AIM start ups like a Junior Gold Explorer / Miner like GRL, it's cash hungry, until the point its not, and it's self sustaining in revenue and positive cash, and its timing this as an PI that is the skill. AIMS / Paracle, and whomever else ponied up this cash obviously think its a good investment, and believe EP is the person to lead it, their information will be better than ours. If you want my tuppence, I believe we will achieve over 2k ounces production in Q1 this year. Hold me to this statement.
